nodes.bodyText: I see some >= for chunkstart checking (line 575 for instance), can you double-check if it's really chunkends[i] > end + chunklen?

chunkends[] keeps track of the last timestamp in a chunk. Each chunk is chunklen time units wide, so we are checking here if the ith chunk ends more than chunklen timeunits after end, making the whole chunk past 'end'

I'm pretty sure it should be chunkends[i] >= end + chunklen because:
chunkends[i] > end + chunklen
= chunkends[i] - chunklen > end
= chunkends[i - 1] > end
= chunkstarts[i] - 1 > end (if chunkstarts was defined, first included tick for each chunk)
Thus, if end == chunkstarts[i] - 1, the i-th chunk will be considered although it does not contain end.
indeed
Can you add a comment to tell if both start and end are included?
As Jetty will use a ThreadPool to manage the handlers threads, thus the threads running the WarpScript, the values will be kept form previous runs. Not sure of this, but seems likely to me.

Indeed, that is why both FETCH and EgressFetchHandler call either cache/nocache and persist/nopersist prior to calling fetch. The only case which should be a concern is when the StoreClient is exposed via 'egress.clients.expose' set to true, as the use of the StoreClient should be preceded by the same logic of calling cache/nocache/persist/nopersist.
Adding a warning in the configuration.
Build the String once.
Shouldn't cacheend be computed using TimeSource.getTime() instead of now?
Is there a reason for not fetching in both persist and cache by spiting the time window according to cachestart and cacheend?
Empty if.

Should the result be deduped to have consistent result between cache and persist?
Or modify the cache so it does not store duplicate ticks.
Also the result will not be sorted using the cache but will be using persist. I don't think this is as problematic as the duplicate ticks is.

The semantics are those of the in-memory store, duplication is not handled at the store level, for the rare cases where you want to avoid duplicates datapoints, simply call DEDUP after FETCH if it was against the in-memory store.
You could  add || !iter.hasNext to avoid adding the if (!batch.isEmpty()) after.

Where do you define the accelerator time range ? What about in.memory.chunked = true ?
There is no warning nor failure if I set in.memory=true, in.memory.chunked = true, accelerator = true.

nodes.bodyText:
Is it a debug function or not ? If so, it should report more than the last fetch status. Maybe a map with :

accelerator activation status
accelerator preload status
accelerator max time depth
last fetch was accelerated
number of gts in the accelerator (help for debug remote customers too) (as directory is not affected, FIND won't make any difference when called after ACCEL.NOPERSIST)

nodes.bodyText:
So it must be a chunked memory store. Warp 10 must fail or warn if not properly configured.
Maybe the most clean will be to have accelerator.chunk.count and accelerator.chunk.length configurations.
Why accelerator.chunk.count and accelerator.chunk.length are mandatory whereas  in.memory.chunk.count and in.memory.chunk.length have default values?

The accelerator will load its in-memory cache with data from disk upon startup, having default values similar to those of in.memory.xxx would lead to massive fetch ops, so better not have default values and force the user to choose wisely.
Shouldn't an error be thrown if nocache.get()?
